<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TAX
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/undefined?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Tax Plan Goes After the Megayacht Crowd
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/undefined?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Warren Buffett, Jeff Bezos, and Elon Musk" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/46628bcd8be09728d9652a244297da937bdf064f-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Photo Illustration: Mick McDougall; Photo: Anadolu Agency, Pool, Spencer Platt/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We mentioned yesterday that Elon Musk’s fortune grew to nearly $290 billion thanks to Tesla’s stock-price surge. Some Democrats have floated a “<a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/25/upshot/biden-tax-billionaires.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">billionaire’s tax</a>” to make Musk and his Perrier-drinking peers send a lot more of that wealth to the government.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The proposal, spearheaded by the Senate Finance Committee chair, Ron Wyden, is an attempt to raise billions in revenue to offset the costs of Democrats’ ~$1.75 trillion spending bill.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">It’s...extremely unusual</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The tax would likely target a smaller group of individuals than any other tax in American history—those with $1 billion in assets, or who earn at least $100 million in income for three consecutive years. It could apply to just <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-26/democrats-new-tax-target-is-5-trillion-in-billionaire-wealth?srnd=premium" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">700 taxpayers</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And what would they be taxed on? <em>Unrealized capital gains</em>. Here’s what that means:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Currently, investments like stocks or real estate are taxed only when they are sold for a profit.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Under the “billionaire’s tax,” you’d be taxed on your investment gains even if you haven’t sold them yet. It would be like taking a stack of chips from your craps winnings before you cashed them in.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The rationale: </strong>The existing tax system is set up in such a way that the ultrawealthy can dramatically lower their tax burden by, for example, getting compensated in stock options rather than a salary like the rest of us. This plan would make that stock taxable.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Plus, it would raise a truly ridiculous amount<em> </em>of money. The richest 169 Americans are sitting on roughly $516 billion in unrealized gains. Elon Musk himself would have to pay <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2021/10/26/billioniare-tax-dems-biden/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">up to $50 billion</a> over the first five years the tax gets implemented, according to one analysis.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Many experts are calling it unworkable</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Or worse. NYU finance professor Aswath Damodaran <a href="https://aswathdamodaran.blogspot.com/2021/10/the-billionaire-tax-worst-tax-idea-ever.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wrote</a> that the proposal is “perhaps the worst thought-through and most ineffective attempt ever at rewriting tax code.” Questions like, “What do you do when an investment goes down?” “How would they come up with the money without selling other assets?” and, “Is this even constitutional?” are not easily answered.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>While some Democrats support the plan, others think it’ll be a logistical nightmare. Still, they’ll need to agree on some way to raise more revenue in order to push their spending bill forward before the week is over. One of those strategies is a <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporate-minimum-tax-resurfaces-as-democrats-hunt-for-money-11635280425?mod=hp_lead_pos2" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">15% minimum tax</a> on large corporations’ profits, which three senators proposed yesterday.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
EDUCATION
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/college-enrollment-could-continue-to-plummet-this-fall?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Flip Cup Could Soon Become a Lost Art
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">More than 500,000 fewer students enrolled in college in 2020 compared to 2019, about a 3% drop, and an additional half-million are expected to have <a href="https://www.npr.org/2021/10/26/1048955023/college-enrollment-down-pandemic-economy?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">torn up</a> their applications this year, according to preliminary data. That would be the biggest two-year enrollment decline in over 50 years, according to the National Student Clearinghouse Research Center.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It's not the Harvards of the world that are hurting for students:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>10% fewer students enrolled in community colleges—which have more low-income students and students of color than four-year schools—in 2020 vs. 2019, and community college enrollment is projected to have dropped another 5.6% this fall.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>That bucks the typical trend: Normally when the economy is doing poorly, all enrollment, but especially community college enrollment, rises as people skip out on the job market to level up their education.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Undergraduate and graduate enrollment has been sliding since 2012, but fell off a cliff when the pandemic kicked everyone off campus last year. Fewer students enrolling now = fewer grads seeking higher-paying jobs later.<em>—JW</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
VENTURE CAPITAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/sequoia-capital-will-no-longer-be-a-venture-capital-firm?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Putting the Fun Back in Fund
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/sequoia-capital-will-no-longer-be-a-venture-capital-firm?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Diving into a money pit" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-26/image-ce741bdcbcfe52389e7bcc8a1f698b43ed93feb4-480x270-gif/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Diving into a money pit" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-10-26/image-ce741bdcbcfe52389e7bcc8a1f698b43ed93feb4-480x270-gif/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Despite every venture capitalist having “adventure capitalist” in their social bios, VC firms are notoriously staid institutions. That’s why Sequoia Capital, one of the biggest and oldest VC firms, is restructuring as just...a fund—hold the VC.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The specifics: </strong>Sequoia is <a href="https://www.axios.com/sequoia-capital-fund-venture-capital-model-36425923-deff-430e-9945-09b0ccb69c78.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rolling up</a> its US and European investments into one big Sequoia Fund, fed by individually managed sub-funds (venture, seed, etc.).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In addition, Sequoia wants to become a “registered investment advisor” (RIA), which will give it more <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/26/sequoia-changes-fund-structure-to-hold-public-companies-and-back-crypto.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">wiggle room</a> to invest in cryptocurrency and public stocks—assets that have been off-limits to traditional venture capital firms.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Andreessen Horowitz made the same switch from VC → RIA two years ago, but it’s overall a rare move that only finance’s biggest players can pull off.</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why?</strong> In a blog post, Sequoia Partner Roelof Botha called the VC model, which operates on short timelines and typically returns money back to investors within 10 years, “outdated” and “the business equivalent of floppy disks.” If Sequoia has a good thing going with a certain startup, it wants to hold on and enjoy the ride.<em>—JW</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/key-performance-indicators-october-27?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/key-performance-indicators-october-27?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Still from 'Dune'" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/2338c4b003444b682e9f3cb4f73dc882252eda3a-600x400.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Dune </em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>A stunning 50% of all of <em>Dune</em>’s domestic box office sales last weekend came from <a href="https://variety.com/2021/film/box-office/dune-box-office-opening-weekend-timothee-chalamet-1235096320/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">premium formats</a>, including IMAX, Dolby, and 4DX. IMAX itself accounted for 22.5% of all market share. Whatever happened, it worked—a <em>Dune </em>sequel was confirmed yesterday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote: </strong>“Thank God for Ted Sarandos and Netflix.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In a new standup show posted to his Instagram, Dave Chappelle <a href="https://deadline.com/2021/10/dave-chappelle-controversy-reaction-video-trans-netflix-hannah-gadsby-1234862068/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">praised</a> the streaming company and its co-CEO for sticking with him in the face of backlash. Chappelle said virtually all other platforms and film festivals have withdrawn their invitations to air his documentary made in summer 2020, <em>Untitled</em>.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
REAL ESTATE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/a-neighborhood-of-100-3d-printed-homes-is-coming-to-austin-in-2022?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
There's No Print Like Home
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/a-neighborhood-of-100-3d-printed-homes-is-coming-to-austin-in-2022?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Rendering of a suburban street lined with 3D-printed homes." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/07a16d69de62ac9a8c5560a41bfb7b62348c6ef3-2500x1413.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Icon/Lennar</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The home of the future might look a lot like toothpaste. 100 3D-printed homes are set to be squeezed out of a nozzle in the Austin area in early 2022, forming the <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/3-d-printed-houses-are-sprouting-near-austin-as-demand-for-homes-grows-11635240601?mod=hp_lead_pos5" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">largest 3D-printed neighborhood</a> in the US.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The development, a partnership between the home construction and real estate company Lennar and 3D printing company Icon, will be a test for the technology. If the neighborhood attracts residents, it could suggest that 3D printing is a viable solution to the home construction industry’s labor shortage and supply chain issues (so long as they don’t run out of cyan).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How a goop becomes a home: </strong>Icon’s 15-and-a-half-foot-tall printers squeeze out layers of concrete like soft serve ice cream. In a week’s time, they can print the exterior and interior walls of a one-story, 2,000-square foot home.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Don’t expect a big discount for buyers, though. According to Lennar, the 3D-printed homes will be priced similarly to other homes in the Austin area—a city recently <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/austin-is-capital-of-homes-selling-at-super-premiums-11629279001?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">described as</a> the “capital of homes selling at super premiums.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Supporters of 3D-printed homes hope the technology’s cheaper building methods and more environmentally friendly assembly can offer solutions to the housing crisis and traditional construction’s carbon footprint.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Word Search: </strong>If you've ever dreamed of donning a cape and saving the world from evil villains, <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/10/26/word-search-superhero-symbols?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">today's puzzle is for you</a>.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">For the Swifties</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On this day in 2014, Taylor Swift released her album <em>1989, </em>home to all-time classics like “Blank Space” and “Bad Blood.” Can you put her nine albums in chronological order?</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Red, Speak Now, Evermore, Lover, Taylor Swift, 1989, Fearless, Folklore, Reputation</em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Once you figure that out...the follow-up question is: Which album is the best?</p>

style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nTax Plan Goes After the Megayacht target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Warren Buffett, Jeff Bezos, and Elon Musk\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/46628bcd8be09728d9652a244297da937bdf064f-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003ePhoto Illustration: Mick McDougall; Photo: Anadolu Agency, Pool, Spencer Platt/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe mentioned yesterday that Elon Musk’s fortune grew to nearly $290 billion thanks to Tesla’s stock-price surge. Some Democrats have floated a “\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/10/25/upshot/biden-tax-billionaires.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebillionaire’s tax\u003c/a\u003e” to make Musk and his Perrier-drinking peers send a lot more of that wealth to the government.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe proposal, spearheaded by the Senate Finance Committee chair, Ron Wyden, is an attempt to raise billions in revenue to offset the costs of Democrats’ ~$1.75 trillion spending bill.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eIt’s...extremely unusual\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe tax would likely target a smaller group of individuals than any other tax in American history—those with $1 billion in assets, or who earn at least $100 million in income for three consecutive years. It could apply to just \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-10-26/democrats-new-tax-target-is-5-trillion-in-billionaire-wealth?srnd=premium\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e700 taxpayers\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd what would they be taxed on? \u003cem\u003eUnrealized capital gains\u003c/em\u003e. Here’s what that means:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCurrently, investments like stocks or real estate are taxed only when they are sold for a profit.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eUnder the “billionaire’s tax,” you’d be taxed on your investment gains even if you haven’t sold them yet. It would be like taking a stack of chips from your craps winnings before you cashed them in.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe rationale: \u003c/strong\u003eThe existing tax system is set up in such a way that the ultrawealthy can dramatically lower their tax burden by, for example, getting compensated in stock options rather than a salary like the rest of us. This plan would make that stock taxable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePlus, it would raise a truly ridiculous amount\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003eof money. The richest 169 Americans are sitting on roughly $516 billion in unrealized gains. Elon Musk himself would have to pay \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/us-policy/2021/10/26/billioniare-tax-dems-biden/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eup to $50 billion\u003c/a\u003e over the first five years the tax gets implemented, according to one analysis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eMany experts are calling it unworkable\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOr worse. NYU finance professor Aswath Damodaran \u003ca href=\"https://aswathdamodaran.blogspot.com/2021/10/the-billionaire-tax-worst-tax-idea-ever.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewrote\u003c/a\u003e that the proposal is “perhaps the worst thought-through and most ineffective attempt ever at rewriting tax code.” Questions like, “What do you do when an investment goes down?” “How would they come up with the money without selling other assets?” and, “Is this even constitutional?” are not easily answered.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile some Democrats support the plan, others think it’ll be a logistical nightmare. Still, they’ll need to agree on some way to raise more revenue in order to push their spending bill forward before the week is over. One of those strategies is a \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/corporate-minimum-tax-resurfaces-as-democrats-hunt-for-money-11635280425?mod=hp_lead_pos2\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e15% minimum tax\u003c/a\u003e on large corporations’ profits, which three senators proposed yesterday.—\u003cem\u003eNF\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nFlip Cup Could Soon Become a Lost Art\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eMore than 500,000 fewer students enrolled in college in 2020 compared to 2019, about a 3% drop, and an additional half-million are expected to have \u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2021/10/26/1048955023/college-enrollment-down-pandemic-economy?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etorn up\u003c/a\u003e their applications this year, according to preliminary data. That would be the biggest two-year enrollment decline in over 50 years, according to the National Student Clearinghouse Research Center.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIt's not the Harvards of the world that are hurting for students:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e10% fewer students enrolled in community colleges—which have more low-income students and students of color than four-year schools—in 2020 vs. 2019, and community college enrollment is projected to have dropped another 5.6% this fall.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThat bucks the typical trend: Normally when the economy is doing poorly, all enrollment, but especially community college enrollment, rises as people skip out on the job market to level up their education.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eUndergraduate and graduate enrollment has been sliding since 2012, but fell off a cliff when the pandemic kicked everyone off campus last year. Fewer students enrolling now = fewer grads seeking higher-paying jobs later.\u003cem\u003e—JW\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDespite every venture capitalist having “adventure capitalist” in their social bios, VC firms are notoriously staid institutions. That’s why Sequoia Capital, one of the biggest and oldest VC firms, is restructuring as just...a fund—hold the VC.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe specifics: \u003c/strong\u003eSequoia is \u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/sequoia-capital-fund-venture-capital-model-36425923-deff-430e-9945-09b0ccb69c78.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erolling up\u003c/a\u003e its US and European investments into one big Sequoia Fund, fed by individually managed sub-funds (venture, seed, etc.).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn addition, Sequoia wants to become a “registered investment advisor” (RIA), which will give it more \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/26/sequoia-changes-fund-structure-to-hold-public-companies-and-back-crypto.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewiggle room\u003c/a\u003e to invest in cryptocurrency and public stocks—assets that have been off-limits to traditional venture capital firms.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAndreessen Horowitz made the same switch from VC → RIA two years ago, but it’s overall a rare move that only finance’s biggest players can pull off.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy?\u003c/strong\u003e In a blog post, Sequoia Partner Roelof Botha called the VC model, which operates on short timelines and typically returns money back to investors within 10 years, “outdated” and “the business equivalent of floppy disks.” If Sequoia has a good thing going with a certain startup, it wants to hold on and enjoy the width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe home of the future might look a lot like toothpaste. 100 3D-printed homes are set to be squeezed out of a nozzle in the Austin area in early 2022, forming the \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/3-d-printed-houses-are-sprouting-near-austin-as-demand-for-homes-grows-11635240601?mod=hp_lead_pos5\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elargest 3D-printed neighborhood\u003c/a\u003e in the US.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe development, a partnership between the home construction and real estate company Lennar and 3D printing company Icon, will be a test for the technology. If the neighborhood attracts residents, it could suggest that 3D printing is a viable solution to the home construction industry’s labor shortage and supply chain issues (so long as they don’t run out of cyan).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow a goop becomes a home: \u003c/strong\u003eIcon’s 15-and-a-half-foot-tall printers squeeze out layers of concrete like soft serve ice cream.
